post_info.post_title: Forbidding scripture in debate, should it be allowed to happen?

Kronus

Forbidding scripture in debate, should it be allowed to happen?

 
 The problem with scripture in debate is that too many people use it in the context of "The Bible says it, therefore it is irrefutably true". There are people here who often reply to posts with just a Biblical citation, as if that were some sort of useful response. If two people both hold the same level of belief in the Bible, than simply swapping citations may constitute useful discussion. However, if the level of belief in the Bible varies among the participants in a debate (and I think we can assume that here) than simply quoting the Bible as if it were fact is no more useful than saying "I say so, therefore it is true" or "my fortune cookie says...". If you don't accept as an axiom "The Bible is true" than you won't accept any argument based on that axiom, and so arguments based on just citing scripture are pretty pointless. Of course, that having been said, citing the Bible is quite justified for supporting one's own personal beliefs.
jyoshu

It depends on what sort of debate you are having. If the debate is within the Biblical context, then I'd say, yes--scripture would be expected. (e.g. is the Trinity a valid Christian concept)
 
 If the debate's context is extra-Biblical, then I'd say no. (e.g. Does the Genesis 6-day creation event fit science as we know it)

 Actually, the subject matter would determine the fallaciousness of the argument. For instance if one is requesting information about the character of God in a thread (eg Why worship God, no scripture please), then it is necessary to use scripture as the definition of God is only found in scripture, if we are to use some form of objective authority. If all that is wanted is my opinion and that there is to be no debate, then it becomes a message board and not a debate board. This board is dedicated to debate is it not?
 
 You will note my arguments in that thread and you will note that I do not specifically limit "scripture" to the bible. I say that I would use the bible as that is where I get my info about God. HOwever, a buddhist, hindu, muslim etc will likely use their own references as to the nature of who god is.
 
 The question of Why worship God is one that asks for info concerning God's nature. If the arguments take the form of "Scripture says we are supposed to" then that would be an illogical argument and actually non topical. HOwever, you will also note, that I have NEVER NEVER said, "because scripture says so." It is not my style. I will use scripture as a reference and then point to the logic of its statements and provide context. 
 
 Others have then argued the context or that I misinterpreted the context etc, but those are legitimate points of argument. 
 
 The problem that I have is not a "whining" as Dr. Sprocket suggests that I cannot do what I want but that the question itself is actually illogical.
 
 To ask a question about the character of God (Why worship GOd) and to then not allow anything that actually describes the character of God to be admitted as evidence is a logical fallacy. It is the same as asking a question such as Who was the greatest batter in the American League and then not allowing batting statistics.
 
 It is an illogical question. Another example is asking "What happens when the irresistable force meets the immovable object?" It is an illogical question because the existence of the irresistable force necessarily precludes the existence of an immovable object by its very definition.
 
 To ask an illogical question and expect logical debate is simply ridiculous.
 
 EF

 Your analogy is interesting, and revealing. I know nothing about the American League, but I assume that its batting statistics are written up in genuinely objective and authoritative tomes (perhaps a bit like our Wisden). Are you really saying that religious scripture is to the nature of god as Wisden (or your equivalent) is to batting averages? (Before you accuse me of straw man tactics, I would point out your phrase 'It is the same as ...').
 
 The notion that scripture has the status of 'objective authority' in this way is to say the least a highly suspect one. Of course. Conservatism, by very definition, is a belief against what is perceived as unnecessary change.  You've applied a little conflation here, I think. Using scripture as a source in answering the question 'Why Worship God?' is not the same as claiming that scripture constitutes 'objective authority on the nature of God'. The strictly human authors of scripture can write down any number of arguments and injunctions on the former, and these can be deployed or dismissed according to merit.  The point is, the OP in that thread was not asking about that nature of God. It was asking 'why worship god'. Those are two entirely different things.
 
 I notice that Maximus, a very devote Catholic, was able to answer it in a very nice manner without refering to scripture. 
 
 Why can't you do the same? Why can't you use your own words?
epaphras_faith

The point is, the OP in that thread was not asking about that nature of God. It was asking 'why worship god'. Those are two entirely different things.
 
 I notice that Maximus, a very devote Catholic, was able to answer it in a very nice manner without refering to scripture. 
 
 Why can't you do the same? Why can't you use your own words?

 
 I did and can. I simply object to it as this is a DEBATE forum and not a "let me throw my opinion around without support" forum. 
 
 oops, I forgot, that is what you call debate.
 
 EF
trebor

I did and can. I simply object to it as this is a DEBATE forum and not a "let me throw my opinion around without support" forum. 
 
 oops, I forgot, that is what you call debate.
 
 EF

 
 In this case, that wasn't what the person wanted. 
 
 Maybe, he wanted to hear what YOUR words were, rather than a cut/paste from someone else.
 
 After all, they are discussing thigns with you, not with a book.
Love Never Dies

For both John and Dr. Sprocket:
 
 Again the question is, if not scripture as an objective authority on the nature of GOd, then what?
 
 I am not limiting it to my god or my assumptions about god. I would expect a muslim who answered that question to provide information about the nature of god from the quran. Taoist from the Tao T'ching etc.
 
 While scripture is generally (by secular society) held to be written by people, there really is no other source for such information. Would you accept the phrase "It is the 'most' objective authority we have on the nature of god."?
 
 EF

 Scripture as an objective authority on the nature of god?
 
 You have got to be kidding me.

post_info.post_title: Leave it hanging out, and we will shoot it off.

Ooaman

Forbidding scripture in debate, should it be allowed to happen?

 As I believe I read someone posted, it depends on the thread at hand. If I was to start up a thread and ask if anyone had any idea where the Arc of the Covenant currently is, there would be no room for it since there isn't anything mentioned in the Bible after either Kings or Samuel. I guess you could quote scripture and quote the 10 commandments one by one or quote about David dancing naked in the street for them. But that would have nothing to do with the question at hand. However, if you can make a point as to why you posted the scripture, then it might make sense.
 On the other hand, if I started a new thread and asked about how long it took the wise men to get to Bethlehem (or how many were there) then scripture is acceptable and if nothing else, make sense as to why it's being used.
johnhanks

For both John and Dr. Sprocket:
 
 Again the question is, if not scripture as an objective authority on the nature of GOd, then what?

 
 You face the fact that no such 'objective authority' exists, that's what.
 
 With respect, your position is akin to a man lost in the Kalahari trying to find his way using Tolkien's map of Middle Earth. 'Look, this is all I've got. If this isn't objective authority, what can I use?'
Love Never Dies

You face the fact that no such 'objective authority' exists, that's what.
 
 With respect, your position is akin to a man lost in the Kalahari trying to find his way using Tolkien's map of Middle Earth. 'Look, this is all I've got. If this isn't objective authority, what can I use?'

 Added to that the religious crew will punch you in the nose if you bring a different map to the party.
 
 They need to defend there "objective authority" you know, to maintain its integrity.
ArchaicGuy

[QUOTE=Ooaman]As I believe I read someone posted, it depends on the thread at hand. If I was to start up a thread and ask if anyone had any idea where the Arc of the Covenant currently is, there would be no room for it since there isn't anything mentioned in the Bible after either Kings or Samuel. I guess you could quote scripture and quote the 10 commandments one by one or quote about David dancing naked in the street for them. But that would have nothing to do with the question at hand. However, if you can make a point as to why you posted the scripture, then it might make sense.
 On the other hand, if I started a new thread and asked about how long it took the wise men to get to Bethlehem (or how many were there) then scripture is acceptable and if nothing else, make sense as to why it's being used.[/QUOTE) The Ark of the Covenant is mentioned in 2 Maccabees. The question would then be what constitutes Sacred Scriptures if it isn't part of the official canon?
epaphras_faith

Scripture as an objective authority on the nature of god?
 
 You have got to be kidding me.

 
 You have no argument here. You have obviously not read anything previous. Please do not interrupt an otherwise intelligent discussion.
 
 EF
epaphras_faith

You face the fact that no such 'objective authority' exists, that's what.
 
 With respect, your position is akin to a man lost in the Kalahari trying to find his way using Tolkien's map of Middle Earth. 'Look, this is all I've got. If this isn't objective authority, what can I use?'

 
 Then we come back to the concept that this is a debate forum. Note the word debate. For a debate to be properly adjudicated there must be an authority. There must be something. Otherwise the question is pointless. We may no only debate things that have little substance.
 
 You can debate all you want on things with no authority but they will always devolve into name calling and the like. Much of which you and I have seen from many members on this board. We may have even participated in it from time to time.
 
 It is actually very prejudicial to limit such things. People are always complaining that christianity is intollerant or exclusive. When the reality is that those that are not christians are usually not tollerant of christians and more than willing to exclude them. I am not saying this of you as you have not displayed that. 
 
 It is truly a shame. 
 
 EF
johnhanks

Then we come back to the concept that this is a debate forum. Note the word debate. For a debate to be properly adjudicated there must be an authority. There must be something. Otherwise the question is pointless. We may no only debate things that have little substance.i

 
 What there must be for a debate, I think, is agreement on its premises and on forms of argument that may legitimately be deployed. Is the former, perhaps, what you mean when you say 'there must be an authority', or do you mean there must be a source to turn to for verification if someone disputes an opponent's factual claim?
 
 My own participation in the current thread was not in response to its OP, as I am too much of a soggy liberal to want to 'forbid' people from deploying their source of choice in debate. (Also, as a non-believer debating believers, I always know I'm winning when their only recourse is to scripture; but that's beside the point.) I came in only in response to your assertion that scripture constitutes 'objective authority', and have said what I have to say. Thank you for your time and your courtesy; by all means have the last word.
foundit66

For both John and Dr. Sprocket:
 Again the question is, if not scripture as an objective authority on the nature of GOd, then what?

 I would say that the scripture is an objective authority FOR YOU regarding YOUR BELIEFS in God.
 And if you are speaking to what your beliefs are on the subject, it would be good to substantiate the source of your beliefs.
 But it should be acknowledged that they are YOUR BELIEFS. Not to be confused with fact. Not to be confused with an unquestionable source.
 
 And furthermore regarding the use of the word "objective", I think it's entirely inaccurate. It would be more accurate to state that it is a SUBJECTIVE authority, as not all people acknowledge that authority.
 
 But to answer your question more explicitly, would it be that much of a real problem if there were NO objective authority?
 
 
 
I am not limiting it to my god or my assumptions about god. I would expect a muslim who answered that question to provide information about the nature of god from the quran. Taoist from the Tao T'ching etc.
 While scripture is generally (by secular society) held to be written by people, there really is no other source for such information. Would you accept the phrase "It is the 'most' objective authority we have on the nature of god."?
 EF

 If Grimm's fairy tales were the only source we had on the history of "Little Red Riding Hood", would that mean it is the "most objective authority"?
 Assuming your assumption true, if there were "no other source for such information", would that mean that it automatically qualifies as an "authority" or "objective"?
 
 You are assuming a lot about the Bible, and I think that is part of the problem with using it as a source. The people who use it often can assume the validity of the source without acknowledging it is a BELIEF and not an "authority".
epaphras_faith

In reply to foundit: You are the one making an assumption. I am not assuming the bible. In fact, if you reread my previous posts in discussion with Johnhanks you will note that I am accepting of any scripture as authority on the nature of God where debate is concerned. Please note that it is on this subject, The Nature of God, on which I believe scripture to be appropriate. For purposes of debate, I made it clear that ANY religious document generally accepted as scripture (The Quran, The torah, etc.) to be reasonable references for someone to use in a debate that specifically concerns the nature of God. In particular "Why worship God". I did not limit it to the bible. It is interesting that you accuse me of assuming a lot about the bible and about my predispositions when you did not bother to read through the previous discussion to learn that I was not describing the bible. You made an assumption about me. I do use the bible as that is indeed MY BELIEF. Others are free to use what they know to be scripture. I do not limit it. It was another thread and poster who limited the discussion by asking about "Why worship God No scripture Please". 
 
 Before you accuse me of things, I do wish you would do even the minimal research of reading through the discussion. Thanks
 
 Johnhanks: By authority I refer to some reference outside the debater themselves that offers a legitimate position and has some expertise in the matter. Another example would be in the topic of economic principles. I could post a rather conservative set of principles arguing for privatization of social security for instance whereas you could post a liberal set of economic principles arguing against it. Neither of us could PROVE one over the other. We would be hardpressed to prove that there was a landslide of evidence in one direction or the other. However, to support our position we would post documents and quotes and pitches from various experts and authorities (those who know something).
 
 To keep with religion, it would be reasonable to use scripture and then also quote some religious personages. From ANY religion. It makes the debate hinge on an actual authority. Otherwise it is my opinion against yours. You and I can do some logical analysis of our opinion (and I try to stick to that because using outside authority on this board seems to degenerate into a validity of the source debate which is hardly useful for purposes of actual debate). 
 
 You see, I am trained in formal debate and I tend to stick to formal debate principles. One of which is that the debater themselves is NEVER an authority on a subject. The debater can assert a position but then must back it up with outside sources in agreement and also analysis of the logic and facts concerning the assertion. It is one of the reasons that Trebor vexes me so. He is ultimately illogical and frequently asserts things with no analyis and the only claim to authority is to himself.
 
 That being said, I also appreciate the discussion and the final courtesy. I shall give the final word to you if you have more on the subject. 
 
 At the risk of injuring my position
 
 God Bless,
 
 EF
foundit66

In reply to foundit: You are the one making an assumption. I am not assuming the bible. In fact, if you reread my previous posts in discussion with Johnhanks you will note that I am accepting of any scripture as authority on the nature of God where debate is concerned. Please note that it is on this subject, The Nature of God, on which I believe scripture to be appropriate.

 In that specific environment, I feel that it is an authority as to what some people believe.
 It may be a semantic quibble, but I feel it is a significant one.
 To me, an "authority" would have to be objectively verifiable. And when it comes to debates of beliefs, "objectivity" isn't really a possibility.
 
 
 
For purposes of debate, I made it clear that ANY religious document generally accepted as scripture (The Quran, The torah, etc.) to be reasonable references for someone to use in a debate that specifically concerns the nature of God. In particular "Why worship God". I did not limit it to the bible. It is interesting that you accuse me of assuming a lot about the bible and about my predispositions when you did not bother to read through the previous discussion to learn that I was not describing the bible. You made an assumption about me. I do use the bible as that is indeed MY BELIEF. Others are free to use what they know to be scripture. I do not limit it. It was another thread and poster who limited the discussion by asking about "Why worship God No scripture Please". 

 And to me, such a discussion would help eliminate some of the arguments which aren't perceived as arguments.
 If a person doesn't believe in the Bible, then it's pointless to "debate" an argument to him based on the Bible. Like arguing "you should worship God to be saved according to the Bible". If the other person doesn't believe God is passing out damnation or salvation, then such an argument is fruitless and wasted. It can't really go anywhere or evolve into a discussion.
 But to another degree, "why worship god" includes a LOT of personal belief issues in the first place where people aren't going to agree. So perhaps limiting it in such a regard is not sensical.
 
 I think to some degree it's also a frustration with some statements like the one Easyrider made earlier in this thread. He said something to the degree that forbidding scripture helps people to ignore the fact that they are violating God's word.
 Can you see how such a false statement can be annoying in an attempt for real debate? Or statements assuming the validity of the Bible, and assuming that the other person actually thinks the bible is valid but chooses to violate it, can be annoying in an attempt for an intellectual debate?
 
 I think the rule (to some degree) is an attempt to separate the wheat from the chaff. Unfortunately, I think some can intelligently bring their beliefs to the table without making such gratingly false claims....
 And for them, it can be a situation where the rule doesn't suit its purpose.
 
 
 
Before you accuse me of things, I do wish you would do even the minimal research of reading through the discussion. Thanks

 I think you misunderstand my statements. If you could explicitly state what you think my "accusation" or "assumption" was, it would help.
 You talked about the scripture being an "objective authority" on God.
 THAT is the basis of my statements. And it may be a purely semantical disjoint between us where we define "objective authority" differently.
 Hopefully my comments above elaborate on where I am coming from.
Easyrider

I think to some degree it's also a frustration with some statements like the one Easyrider made earlier in this thread. He said something to the degree that forbidding scripture helps people to ignore the fact that they are violating God's word. Can you see how such a false statement can be annoying in an attempt for real debate? Or statements assuming the validity of the Bible, and assuming that the other person actually thinks the bible is valid but chooses to violate it, can be annoying in an attempt for an intellectual debate?

 
 Careful, or a spiritually-inspired passage might just pop up and tweak your carnal conscience!
Love Never Dies

Careful, or a spiritually-inspired passage might just pop up and tweak your carnal conscience!

 Cant argue with that!
johnhanks

Cant argue with that!

 One of the rare occasions when an omitted apostrophe improves the sense of the statement. A dash between the first and second words would have made it perfect.
